Award.AbstractNarration:
The University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) is a consortium of sixty-one U.S. academic institutions with research and educational programs in the ocean sciences and dedication to the major shared-use facilities that support these programs. These institutions support a broad array of facilities, which include research vessels, submersibles, remotely operated vehicles, autonomous underwater vehicles, aircraft, icebreakers, major instrumentation, and national facilities. The institution or the supporting federal agencies own these shared-use assets and it is through the UNOLS system that the community is able to access them.

The PI's request funding to host the UNOLS Office beginning in May 2009. As one of the founding institutions of UNOLS, GSO has a long tradition and deep experience with this organization and with the federal agencies that fund it. Since its inception in 1971, UNOLS has played an increasingly important role in coordinating and improving the operations of the nation's academic research fleet. Because the organization functions largely through the voluntary efforts of scientists and professionals from across the country, it is essential that the UNOLS Office be staffed by people who thoroughly understand UNOLS and are committed to its success.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS), an organization consisting of 62 academic institutions with significant marine research and education programs, is charged with advising Federal funding agencies on future facility requirements for ocean science research and coordinating and scheduling UNOLS research vessels and equipment. It is through the coordination work of the UNOLS Office staff that the activities of UNOLS are carried out by elected and appointed members of the scientific community and facility operators serving on the UNOLS Council, standing committees, subcommittees, and ad hoc committees.  The financial support provided by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the Office of Naval Research (ONR), the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), the United States Geological Survey (USGS), and the Bureau of Ocean Energy Management, (BOEM) made it possible for the UNOLS Office to carry out the activities.

In our first term, (2009-2014),  the UNOLS Office, based at the University of Rhode Island's Graduate School of Oceanography, (URI-GSO), successfully managed many programs. Some of the key roles which UNOLS performs is to facilitate ship scheduling, organize workshops, and coordinate the work of the UNOLS Council and our nine standing committees. The broader impact of the research cruise expeditions, workshops, and the knowledge gained by these activities is a direct contribution to society and the public welfare. The improvements to the UNOLS facilities over the past five years will help to optimize at-sea science research operations and enable discoveries which we will all benefit from.  The UNOLS Office successfully met various challenges as they arose and we maintained our effectiveness and resilency. Some of the key accomplishments of our first term include the development of new ways to engage the next generation of sea-going scientists. This included creating early career opportunities such as chief scientist training workshops, user workshops, presenting at national oceanographic conferences and holding webinars.

We worked with our federal partners on fleet modernization efforts including bringing three new oceanographic ships into the fleet. We reached out to students, scientists, technicians, and ship operators to detemine the future science questions and the tools and infrastructure that is required to meet these needs.

The UNOLS Office expanded its reach by working with international organizations.  We coordinated with an international marine technician organization on plans for hosting the INMARTECH 2015 symposium in the US.  We also joined an international research vessel ship operators organization. This resulted in stronger collaborations which led to international barters of ship time and sharing of knowledge across borders.

We developed a new web site which enabled us to more effectively reach across all our user groups. Various UNOLS publications were updated such as the UNOLS Research Vessel Safety Standards. We created a new shipboard safety training film and a gender climate at sea film, both aimed at improving overall safety for the scientists and crew members who go to sea.

We partnered with our federal agencies to identify cost saving measures in a budget climate that has not increased in recent years.

Since our founding in 1971, the UNOLS model has been successful in supporting and strenghtening the field of academic oceanography. The current UNOLS Office at URI-GSO continues to build upon our successes and remains effective, efficient, and engaged.
